body: Is there a workaround? It works well with `mlflow run` though.
[git for windows](https://gitforwindows.org/) might solve the issue.
@harupy In what way would [git for windows](https://gitforwindows.org/) solve the issue? I've just installed it and I see no changes?
sorry git for windows seems unrelated to this issue.

@mpbrigham I have tried `mlflow models serve -m runs:/75614813307443a48a8c6fb80b9959d5/model --no-conda` using python 3.8 + macbook pro, but wasn't able to reproduce the issue. Looks like this is a windows specific issue.
Thank you so much for your support @harupy! How can I help troubleshoot this issue?
I'm still not sure why this issue is happening
Can you veriy subprocess.popen works by running some command?

Yes, this works as expected:
```
import subprocess
subprocess.Popen("dir c:", shell=True)
```

Nope, doesn't work (Python 3.8):
```
>>> subprocess.Popen(["dir c:".split(" ")])
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "Z:\miniconda3\envs\autorouting_v1\lib\subprocess.py", line 854, in __init__
    self._execute_child(args, executable, preexec_fn, close_fds,
  File "Z:\miniconda3\envs\autorouting_v1\lib\subprocess.py", line 1247, in _execute_child
    args = list2cmdline(args)
  File "Z:\miniconda3\envs\autorouting_v1\lib\subprocess.py", line 549, in list2cmdline
    for arg in map(os.fsdecode, seq):
  File "Z:\miniconda3\envs\autorouting_v1\lib\os.py", line 818, in fsdecode
    filename = fspath(filename)  # Does type-checking of `filename`.
TypeError: expected str, bytes or os.PathLike object, not list
```

However, these work as expected (Python 3.8):

```
subprocess.Popen(["dir"], shell=True)
subprocess.Popen(["dir", "c:"], shell=True)
```

It seems to be working with Python 3.7:
```
>>> subprocess.Popen(["dir c:".split(" ")], shell=True)
<subprocess.Popen object at 0x0000022CA7AC0780>
>>> 'dirc:' is not recognized as an internal or external command,
operable program or batch file.
```

I get a different error with Python 3.7:
```
2020/08/26 16:34:49 INFO mlflow.models.cli: Selected backend for flavor 'python_function'
2020/08/26 16:34:49 INFO mlflow.pyfunc.backend: === Running command 'waitress-serve --host=127.0.0.1 --port=5000 --ident=mlflow mlflow.pyfunc.scoring_server.wsgi:app'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "z:\miniconda3\envs\mlflow-ee3a87122ef0e9459a6c20857bfb1b865b86ba87\lib\runpy.py", line 193, in _run_module_as_main
    "__main__", mod_spec)
  File "z:\miniconda3\envs\mlflow-ee3a87122ef0e9459a6c20857bfb1b865b86ba87\lib\runpy.py", line 85, in _run_code
    exec(code, run_globals)
  File "Z:\miniconda3\envs\mlflow-ee3a87122ef0e9459a6c20857bfb1b865b86ba87\Scripts\mlflow.exe\__main__.py", line 7, in <module>
  File "z:\miniconda3\envs\mlflow-ee3a87122ef0e9459a6c20857bfb1b865b86ba87\lib\site-packages\click\core.py", line 829, in __call__
    return self.main(*args, **kwargs)
  File "z:\miniconda3\envs\mlflow-ee3a87122ef0e9459a6c20857bfb1b865b86ba87\lib\site-packages\click\core.py", line 782, in main
    rv = self.invoke(ctx)
  File "z:\miniconda3\envs\mlflow-ee3a87122ef0e9459a6c20857bfb1b865b86ba87\lib\site-packages\click\core.py", line 1259, in invoke
    return _process_result(sub_ctx.command.invoke(sub_ctx))
  File "z:\miniconda3\envs\mlflow-ee3a87122ef0e9459a6c20857bfb1b865b86ba87\lib\site-packages\click\core.py", line 1259, in invoke
    return _process_result(sub_ctx.command.invoke(sub_ctx))
  File "z:\miniconda3\envs\mlflow-ee3a87122ef0e9459a6c20857bfb1b865b86ba87\lib\site-packages\click\core.py", line 1066, in invoke
    return ctx.invoke(self.callback, **ctx.params)
  File "z:\miniconda3\envs\mlflow-ee3a87122ef0e9459a6c20857bfb1b865b86ba87\lib\site-packages\click\core.py", line 610, in invoke
    return callback(*args, **kwargs)
  File "z:\miniconda3\envs\mlflow-ee3a87122ef0e9459a6c20857bfb1b865b86ba87\lib\site-packages\mlflow\models\cli.py", line 59, in serve
    host=host)
  File "z:\miniconda3\envs\mlflow-ee3a87122ef0e9459a6c20857bfb1b865b86ba87\lib\site-packages\mlflow\pyfunc\backend.py", line 98, in serve
    subprocess.Popen([command.split(" ")], env=command_env).wait()
  File "z:\miniconda3\envs\mlflow-ee3a87122ef0e9459a6c20857bfb1b865b86ba87\lib\subprocess.py", line 800, in __init__
    restore_signals, start_new_session)
  File "z:\miniconda3\envs\mlflow-ee3a87122ef0e9459a6c20857bfb1b865b86ba87\lib\subprocess.py", line 1207, in _execute_child
    startupinfo)
FileNotFoundError: [WinError 2] The system cannot find the file specified
```

According to the documentation of [`subprocess.Popen`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/subprocess.html#subprocess.Popen):

> On Windows, if args is a sequence, it will be converted to a string in a manner described in Converting an argument sequence to a string on Windows. This is because the underlying CreateProcess() operates on strings.

The error under `--no-conda` is caused by line 98 in module `mlflow.pyfunc.backend.serve` (mlflow 1.10.0):
```
subprocess.Popen([command.split(" ")], env=command_env).wait()
```
where `command` is a string such as `waitress-serve --host=127.0.0.1 --port=5000 --ident=mlflow mlflow.pyfunc.scoring_server.wsgi:app`. A workaround is to provide the string `command` as argument to `subprocess.Popen()`:
```
subprocess.Popen(command, env=command_env).wait()
```
This workaround was successfully tested with:
* Python 3.5, 3.6, 3.7, and 3.8
* Anaconda Prompt and Anaconda Powershell Prompt
When will this be fixed? It seems to me like all thats needed is the workaround of @mpbrigham to be merged into the repo. I just ran into this bug, and the workaround also fixed the issue for me.

Thank you @mpbrigham, I have patched my local installation of mlflow with your fix.

The piece of code to edit is here, on line 99 : D:\Python\venv\\.mlflow\Lib\site-packages\mlflow\pyfunc\backend.py
I installed mlflow on a virtual environment named ".mlflow".
